lg.head: uraippāṭṭumaṭai
muṉṟiṟciṟappu
vaḷḷukkūttu
muṉṉilaipparaval
veṉṟikkūttu
kūttuḷ paṭutal
lg.l: māyañcey vāḷavuṇar vīḻanaṅkai marakkāṉmēl vāḷamalaiyāṭum pōlum
māyañcey vāḷavuṇar vīḻanaṅkai marakkāṉmēl vāḷamalaiyāṭu māyiṉ
kāyā malarmēṉi yētti vāṉōr kaipey malarmāri kāṭṭum pōlum.
lg.head: veṭci
lg.l: uṭkuṭai cīṟū rorumakaṉā ṉiraikoḷḷa vuṟṟa kālai
veṭci malarpuṉaiya veḷvā ḷuḻattiyum vēṇṭum pōlum
veṭci malarpuṉaiya veṉvā ḷuḻattiyum vēṇṭiṉ vēṟṟūrk
lg.head: veṭcippuṟanaṭai
lg.l: kaḷvilai yāṭṭi maṟuppap poṟāmaṟavaṉ kaivi lēntip
puḷḷum vaḻippaṭarap pullār niraikarutip pōkum pōlum
puḷḷum vaḻippaṭarap pullār niraikarutip pōkuṅ kālaik
koḷḷuṅ koṭiyeṭuttuk koṟṟavaiyuṅ koṭumara muṉcellum pōlum.
lg.head: kōṭai
avippali
palikkoṭai

div.lg:
[Kaṇṇaki and party] having obtained trembling sorrow,
From the wringing by the harsh rays [of the sun], As the little feet reddened from the suffering of going on the path,
As though [she with] fragrant, many tresses sighed short, many [sighs],
They sat over there in order to cool the pain they suffered.
On one side that was unreachable [by most], in the enclosure of Aiyai.
The soothsayer woman (Cāliṉi) with a thunderous voice that had an ancient duty
Of the inheritance of the brave clan with broad hands on which bows wandered,
The god having possessed [her], her hairs standing up,
Raising her hand, Having moved [her] feet, dancing, in the village common in the middle of the village
Where the Eyiṉar participate/come together [within] the fence [upon which] thorns [were] placed,
So that the forest-inhabitants are amazed, [said:]
The groups of herds in loud, big villages [of our enemies] are excellence.
The village common [i.e., the stores] of the Eyiṉar tribe with strong bows have experienced ruin.
The Eyiṉar too, have become silent [i.e., obedient], having ceased [to resist]
[Just] like a clan of [followers of] Dharma,
The wealth [that follows] the path of the inheritance from the brave clan having decreased.
If not [for your being] indebted to the lady that sits on a stag,
She is not one who gives victory that sits on [your] bows.
If it is that you desire a livelihood of drinking fermented liquors,
People who eat by robbery must pay debts!’ Saying thus,
Besides the Eyiṉar tribe that count, having put down heads,
Circling a chosen, young girl from an ancient clan that has not declined
Having pointed [her out],
With a young one of a small, white snake [as] a thread,
Tying a long, hair-knot [out of her] tresses with short [i.e., tight] curls,
Besides [only] plucking [off] the curved, white tusk of a boar
That had fallen in the garden surrounded by guards
Adorning it, saying, ‘it is the sprouting [= crescent] white moon,
Fastening [on her] in a row a Tāli [= necklace] a garland of white teeth
That was obtained, having split [open] the mouth of a strong tiger taken with valour,
Making wear a girdle of animal hide of the pure back [of the tiger]
Upon which were mixed stripes and dots,
With affection,
Bending a black bow, giving [it] into [her] hands,
Mounted [her] upon a stag with twisted antlers,
Praising [her], being the ones who give [her]
A doll, a parakeet, pretty wings [made of] feathers,
A jungle fowl, a blue-coloured peacock,
A ball and Molucca beans,
As the Eyiṟṟi women [under command] come after [the girl], as those who lift
Colour[-pastes], powders, cool, fragrant sandal,
Boiled [rice], sesame [balls], greasy cooked foods,
Flowers, incense and desirable fragrances,
As they sounded, having brought together,
The Paṟai drum that beats [according to] the [traditional] way,
The pillaging horn, the conch, the flute and the great bell,
Placing [those instruments] before the fearful deity [= the girl dressed as a deity],
Praising, having worshipped with [their] hands, the vehicle that was the stag in motion,
On the altar with flower-offerings, where the offering [that is the price] is eaten,
As she [the girl] spoke, the god having possessed her,
About [Kaṇṇaki with] abundant tresses [of] a union that was with [her] husband,
[Kaṇṇaki], suffering, being the one whose little feet [like] twin-blossoms ached,
“As for her, The prosperous lady of the Koṅku land, the lady of the western mountains,
The doll of the southern Tamil [lands], the tender sprout of the penance that was done:
[She is] the sacred, great jewel that is superior in the world, as a singular, great jewel!”
[Kaṇṇaki], having said, ‘The woman of ancient knowledge has spoken a foolish thing!’,
Having concealed herself behind the large back of [her] husband who is difficult to obtain [= special],
As she stood, being one upon whom a new smile budded,
[With] a head that wore a white sliver of the moon,
With an unblinking eye that tore open [on her] forehead,
She with a coral mouth, she with an ash-white, bright smile,
She with a throat that had blackened, having consumed poison,
Having fastened a snake as a thread in hot anger, she who made bend the large mountain,
She with a breast-belt [made of] a serpent with hollow teeth
Having held up a lance in her hand that possessed bangles,
Having wrapped [herself] in elephant-hide,
The woman with a girdle [made of] lion-skin,
That became a fearful female deity,
[Her] individual, little feet with tinkling anklets and [other] anklets,
Koṟṟavai of truth and brightness, of a strong [kind of] victory,
Who is worshipped by many, [such as]
The woman who stood on top of the head of the Asura with round shoulders, in two different forms,
The Amari, Kumar, Kavuri [and] Camari,
The one with the trident, the blue one, the young relative to Māl
Aiyai [= Kāvunti], the red one, [the one with] a hot sword, [the one with] broad hands,
The girl with a leaping stag, the girl with green[-gold] bracelets,
And the beauteous, young girl with the beauty of a young girl
To whom the girl of the choice arts, the girl with rare jewellery
And her own people came to worship,
Graced [the village], because the performance of the Vari dance
Was indeed excellent.
The Nākam tree and fragrant bitter orange were dense;
The Āvu tree and sandal trees were high;
Everywhere, the Cēvu and mango were tight[ly crowded together]
[In] the front yard with the offerings for her who possessed
An eye [on] the forehead [and] a man [as one] half.
The kino trees overflowed in refined gold[en flowers];
Red petals heaped [upon] the branches of good silk-cotton trees;
White specks [=pollen] spilled [over] on the branch of the Puṉku tree
In the brilliant front yard of her with the matted locks [upon which] the young moon lives.
Kadamba, trumpet flower, Puṉṉai, the bottle flower fragrant with scent,
[And] the Kōṅkam flowered; upon branches, groups of noisy bees buzzing,
They would create together [the sound of] the lute,
In the brilliant front yard of her who was young[er than] the brilliant Māl.
What, pray, is the penance [done by] this golden-braceleted girl
Who stood [here], having taken [on] the adornments of Koṟṟavai?
Among all clans, the lineage in which [this] golden-braceleted girl was born
Is the very clan into which the hunters [who] work [with] bows were born.
What, pray, is the penance [done by] this [girl with] a vulva [like] the hooded snake [= cobra]
Who stood, having taken [on] the adornments of the brilliance of Aiyai?
Among all clans, the lineage into which [the girl with] a vulva [like] the hooded snake
Was born, is the very clan into which the Eyiṉar tribe [with] shooting bows were born.
What, pray, is the penance [done by] this good one
Who stood, having taken [on] the adornments of the girl [on] the leaping stag?
Among all clans, the lineage into which the good one with choice bracelets was born
Is the very clan into which the Eyiṉar [with] bamboo bows were born.
Having covered yourself with elephant hide, wearing the skin of a tiger,
You indeed stand upon the difficult head of the forest buffalo.
Being the [ultimate] secret [even] above the Veda, -
So that the celestials bow, -
Becoming the sprout of wisdom, you stand [here] without trembling!
Holding up a sword in [your] hand with striped bangles, killing the great Mahiṣa,
You indeed stand upon the top of the stag with black, twisted antlers.
Being the lamp of light with expanding rays that is permanent
Upon the heart-blossoms of Hari, Hara and he who is upon the flower,
You stand [here]!
Holding up [in your] lotus-hand a conch and a discus,
You indeed stand upon an angry bull - an animal with red eye-streaks.
Being [in your] form the lady of [one] part
Of he with a forehead [with] an eye, who adorned Gaṅgā to [his] hair-knot,
You stand [here] while the Vedas praise [you]!
There,
Having placed upon [her] shoulders a garland of dense[ly packed] blossoms
In which laburnum and Tulsi were linked together,
The dance in the adornment of a girl
That was danced for the immortals, so that the demons fade,
Will [now] take place.
It seems the lady will [now] dance the abundance of the sword upon a wooden leg, so that the demons with swords that create deception fall.
Even if the lady dances the abundance of the sword upon a wooden leg so that the demons with swords that create deception fall,
It seems the celestials, having praised [her] body [like] an ironwood blossom,
Will show a rain of pouring flowers [from their] hands.
In a small town of dread,
When one son was engaged, in order to take [= sieze] a row of cows,
It seems it is necessary for her whose plough is a white sword to decorate [him with] Veṭci blossoms.
If it is necessary for her whose plough is a white sword to decorate [him with] Veṭci blossoms,
It seems that in a different town, in a battle [over there],
It seems that crows [literally, black things], will show, having sounded [their] fierce voices.
A brave man, holding up a bow [in his hand],
Not bearing as a saleswoman of toddy refuses [him],
As even the birds set out on [their own] way,
[Instead], it seems [he] would go, having intended upon the herd of the enemies.
When [he] goes, having intended upon the herd of the enemies
Even as the birds set out on [their own] way,
It seems Koṟṟavai too, having raised [her] banner that conquers,
would go in front of [his] bent tree [= his bow].
O young, dark hunter-girl: see these [things]:
The cow herds that your lord has given in the hunt [already] on the first day
Have filled [up] the front yards of the smith, the player of the Tuṭi drum [and]
The bard of the good lute [with] the skills of the rhythm uniting [with] the melody.
Oh young one [with] a sprout-like smile! See these [things]:
The group of herds that were seized by your lord
So that the [victims of] the Karantai [situation] wept,
Have filled [up] the front yards of the toddy saleswoman,
The man of the forest who understands the good [art of] spying,
[And] the astrologer who spoke the opportunity [= the omens] of the birds.
Oh you with collyrium[-rimmed] eyes [like] pond-blossoms! Look!
The herds of good cows that your lord overthrew,
So that the neigbouring village cried,
Have filled the courtyards of
The Eyiṉar men and Eyiṟṟi women, with grey, old beards
Of undesireable [= unrefined] speech.
We worship your pair of feet that grace,
So that the afflictions of the sages and immortals
That roam [about] with the [thing that] glows [= the sun] get lost.
This is the due that touch your feet [by] the hunters strong in killing;
Take the blood shed [from] the necks [of enemies] [as] the price that gives victory.
Oh you of the colour of sapphire, to whom
The immortals with adorned hair-knots, along with kings, give [their] humility,
We worship your pretty, blossom-feet;
This is the due put [down by] the Eyiṉ tribe of the victory obtained [through] the herd [of cattle];
The price of killing that is comparable [= equal to] the taking of blood shed from fat [=flesh].
As the small Paṟai drum along with the Tuṭi drum make a pound[ing noise]
Along with the bugle/horn, so that thunderous [sounds] happen,
The Eyiṉar people, being like murderous tigers, are those who come
In the mid-darkness. Oh girl, this is the due that falls, that touches your feet —
The collection of faces [as] the offering that is shed [= put down before you].
You eat the due of the Eyiṉar with strong arrows, possessing bows
So that wealth happens [on] all the paths, wanderers having multiplied.
O Caṅkari (eacebringer), o Antari (you of the space), o Nīli (blue one),
You will unite the red-eyed snake to the crescent moon [on your] matted top-knot.
You will eat the due that was put by the compassionless Eyiṉars
That overthrow a sleeping village with [the sound of] a tuṭi that says ‘tuṇ’ [= piercing sound].
When the celestials, despite eating [only] ambrosia die,
You, continuously eating the poison that not a single person eats, grace [the world].
You eat the dues put by the Eyiṉar without grace towards anybody,
Besides if [they] make wounds [= are battling], having taken the wealth [of their enemies].
Having walked [amongst] myrobalan [trees],
Having kicked the rolling wheel of deceit that was done by your uncle,
You grace [the world].
The man of the hill [called] Potiyil, high in heavy [rocks],
Where dwell those who are after the ancient first one of the Vedas,
May he who is keen on victory, wear the Veṭci,
So that the forests/battlefields and Karantai [situations]
In others’ lands fall to ruin.
